p: Similar models are increasingly used for other plant pathogens at both small [ 11– 13, 18, 24– 26, 39– 42] and large spatial scales [ 10, 16, 36, 43– 47]. An emerging epidemic to which models are already being applied is sudden oak death (caused by Phytophthora ramorum) in the United Kingdom [ 48]: predictions from a larger-scale stochastic compartmental model are already informing the extent of felling of commercial larch [ 49]. The United Kingdom government’s response to Chalara ash dieback is also based on predictions from this type of model [ 50]. Models with static hosts have also been applied to pathogens of agricultural animals, most notably for epidemics of foot and mouth disease.
